indicators.justification:
Data on emissions is available on the website of the National Environment Agency (Umwelt BundesAmt) (1). It seems that some individual datasets are available on the open data portal of the German Government GovData.de (2). However, the datasets found via a rapid search were only state-specific or emissions-specific. It is unclear whether the entire national emission dataset is available as open data on the Open Data portal. 
The same datasets are also available on the database of the Federal Office for Statistics (Destatis) (3).

SOURCES: 
(1) Umwelt Bundesamt - Klima. Link: https://www.umweltbundesamt.de/daten/klima
(2) Das Datenportal für Deutschland. Link: https://www.govdata.de/
(3) Federal Office of Statistics webpage. Link: https://www.destatis.de/EN/Home/_node.html

indicators.justification:
The red list centre (1) publishes the red lists approximately every 10 years. The centre falls under the umbrella of the Federal Agency for the protection of nature (2). The lists are compiled on the basis of information collected by the states' institutions and the contribution of experts and organisations, sometimes on a voluntary basis. 
The lists are available as PDF and Excel format and can be downloaded from the website. The categories covered by the lists are quite extensive and there is a dataset (excel and/or pdf) for each category. There is no global dataset of endangered species. 
It seems that the Centre uses its own categories for species and its own classification of risks. However it recognizes the IUCN classification and provides information on how to interpret the datasets (glossary, methodology, etc.). 

SOURCES: 
(1) Rote Liste Zentrum website. Link: https://www.rote-liste-zentrum.de/index.html
(2) Bundesamt für Naturschutz website. Link: https://www.bfn.de/themen/rote-liste.html

indicators.justification:
The Transparency Register is currently under reform to be implemented in the summer 2021) (1). Hence, some information may change in the coming months (e.g. open license, format of data available, obligations to report for all companies). There are currently three relevant registers in German: commerce register (displaying company information)(2), the transparency register (information on beneficial ownership) (3), and the company register (on company data) (4). Companies will have until 2023 to provide full accurate information on the Transparency Register.
All registers have a pay-wall and the researcher was not able to access the information.

SOURCES: 

(1) Stefanie Skoruppa, Tina Hoffmann, Extensive Reporting Requirements to the German Transparency Register for German and Foreign Companies to Come, 2021. Link: https://www.mayerbrown.com/en/perspectives-events/publications/2021/03/extensive-reporting-requirements-to-the-german-transparency-register-for-german-and-foreign-companies-to-come
(2) Commerce register. Link: https://www.handelsregister.de/rp_web/welcome.do?language=en&sec_ip=158.181.83.132
(3) Transparency register. Link: https://www.transparenzregister.de/treg/de/start;jsessionid=8A7769EB331EB3F62993DAB8B1CBCC39.app11?0
(4) Company register. Link: https://www.unternehmensregister.de/ureg/?submitaction=language&language=en

indicators.justification:
Capacity of the healthcare system data is available from government websites (Federal Office of Statistics Deutschland-Dashboard platform and the regional equivalent) (1). In addition, there is a platform for federal health reporting (Das Infor­mations­system der Gesund­heits­bericht­erstat­tung des Bundes) (2). 

Data on the intensive care capacity is available from the platform of the DIVI (Deutschen Interdisziplinären Vereinigung für Intensiv- und Notfallmedizin - German Interdisciplinary Association for Intensive and Emergency Medicine) (3) and the Robert Koch Institute (RKI) (4). 

Real time data is available primarily on intensive unit and respiratory care through DIVI and the RKI as it is one of the indicators used by authorities to monitor the development of Covid-19. 

Other datasets mentioned here are not available with such level of details but provide other type of data (e.g. on general capacity of the healthcare system). The dataset is identified for each survey question. 

RKI provides information on the test capacity per day and per week, as well as general information on tests (type) on their website. 
Vaccination data is available on the platform created for this purpose by the Ministry of Health (5). 

SOURCES: 
(1) Destatis - Gesundheit. Link: https://www.destatis.de/DE/Themen/Gesellschaft-Umwelt/Gesundheit/_inhalt.html
(2) Das Infor­mations­system der Gesund­heits­bericht­erstat­tung des Bundes. Link: https://www.gbe-bund.de/gbe/pkg_isgbe5.prc_isgbe
(3) DIVI Intensivregister. Link: https://www.intensivregister.de/#/intensivregister
(4) Robert Koch Institut - Coronavirus. Link: https://www.rki.de/DE/Home/homepage_node.html
(5) Vaccination dashboard of the Ministry of Health. Link: https://impfdashboard.de/

evidence.title: Das Infor­mations­system der Gesund­heits­bericht­erstat­tung des Bundes

indicators.justification:
The RKI (1) produces data on the number of doses administered. This dataset is available with an open license and free of charge. The variables are: 
- place of administration (to the level of the landkreis), 
- first/second dose, 
- vaccine name, 
- priority group (3 groups in Germany, info available here: https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/corona-informationen-impfung/corona-impfverordnung-1829940
- date
- age group (3 groups)

Another dataset is available online through a platform created by the Ministry of Health specifically to monitor the vaccination campaign (2). 
(note: a VPN might be necessary to access this platform)
This platform provides data on the number of doses delivered and the porportion of doses administered.

Datasets on the caracteristics of the population vaccinated are not available from these platforms. Data on the priority gorup informs on the characteristics of the person receiving the dose.

SOURCES: 
(1) Downloadable data from the RKI on vaccination. Link: https://github.com/robert-koch-institut
(2) Vaccination dashboard of the Ministry of Health. Link: https://impfdashboard.de/

indicators.justification:
Matters related to the budget are regulated by the Budgetary Principles Act (Haushaltsgrundsätzegesetz) (1). 

Budget data is available on several data portals, including Germany's open data portal GovData.de (2). Other sources are the website of the Ministry of finance providing an interactive platform to view budget data (3), and the data portal of the Ministry of finance (4) that is the initial provider for the GovData portal. 

The budget code defines the classification for revenue and expenditures: 
- specific type (object)
- functional area
- group 
This classification does not mention any specific international classification but it is expected that this is not an unusual classification. 

Data on specific cross-sectional items such as the SDGs or climate action fall into various categories of the budget and are not displayed on the datasets under assessment. However, this data may be available in other datasets or specific Ministry webpage. 

There is no evidence that the budget data is provided on an accrual basis.

The data assessed covers the federal budget. Individual states have their own budget and Ministries. 

SOURCES: 
(1) Budgetary Principles Act of 19 August 1969 (Federal Law Gazette I, p. 1273), last amended by Article 1 of the Act of 15 July 2013 (Federal Law Gazette I, p. 2398). Link: https://www.bundesfinanzministerium.de/Content/EN/Gesetze/Laws/1969-08-19-budgetary-principles-act.html
(2) GovData.de - Bundeshaushalt. Link: https://www.govdata.de/web/guest/suchen/-/searchresult/q/bundeshaushalt/s/relevance_desc
(3) Bundeshaulhalt.de - BMF. Link: https://www.bundeshaushalt.de/#
(4) Das Datenportal des BMF. Link: https://www.bundesfinanzministerium.de/Datenportal/start.html

indicators.justification:
The data assessed here is the Public List of Associations Registered with the Bundestag (Öffentliche Liste über die beim Bundestag registrierten Verbände) (1). This list will remain valid until 1 March 2022, until the Lobby register as per the Lobbyregister Act voted in April 2021 enters into force (2).

indicators.justification:
There are some requirements for publication of the results of consultations as per the legal framework (1). 
The agreement on increasing transparency (2) mentions that there is currently no central platform for publishing and that until there is, institutions should use their own website to publish data. This results in a relatively fragmented and difficult to navigate environment to find information on consultations. As there are no requirement regarding what exactly is to be published or who is to be consulted, the data available varies from Ministries to Ministries. Generally, the comments are published but do not necessarily require action and/or response from the Ministry in charge. 
The data covered here concerns only the federal government and its activities. Individual states may have more developed frameworks and databases on public consultations.

SOURCES: 
(1) Joint Rules of Procedure of the Federal Ministries (GGO), 2020. Link: https://www.bmi.bund.de/SharedDocs/downloads/EN/themen/moderne-verwaltung/ggo_en.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=6

indicators.justification:
The dataset assessed here is service.bund.de (1). Other public procurement platforms exist and it is unclear to what extent they overlap/complement one another. 
eVergabe (2) is a more detailed platform but it does not contain as many tenders/public procurement items as the service.bund.de platform. 
Generally, the public procurement system in Germany follows EU thresholds and all tenders above EU thresholds are published on the relevant EU platforms (TED, EUJO). 
GovData.de (3) also publishes data on public procurement but datasets only covers specific geographic areas and no dataset is available as a whole. 
The OpenTender platform (4) provides the most comprehensive information on tenders in Germany. The initiative is led by think tanks and NGOs and provides information on tenders in many countries.

indicators.justification:
The Act on data re-use (IWG and the future DNG) (1) cover the legal frame in which data can be re-used, if not already covered by a specific legal framework (example: freedom fo information Act). 
The strategies (data strategy -Jan 2021- and open data strategies - July 2021) cover the actions planned by the government. Both strategies cover data re-use (2) (3). 
The situation is currently not clear in Germany because the legal framework is under discussion and the open data strategy was adopted in July 2021 and falls outside of the scope of this survey. Hence, the 'part' responses in the survey may soon be corrected because Germany is changing its framework.
Important note: the frameworks assessed here are federal frameworks (legal and strategies). There is evidence that some states have their own open data strategy and provide support for data reuse. These are not covered here but information on states support initiatives are listed in the events section of the GoData.de portal (4)

indicators.justification:
Evidence of the first open data initiative dates back to 2013. However, this does not mean that there was no activities or talks about open data in Germany before this date. In 2013, Germany signed the Open Data Charter of the G8 and work started on what is now called the first Open Data law (EGovG, 2017). (1) (2) This law sets up the first legal frame for open data and has been since then accompanied to data protection laws, freedom of information laws, etc. (see governance section for more details on the legal framework). The initiative on open data is currently active and the German government launched in January 2021 a 'Data strategy' (3) that was followed in July 2021 by an 'Open Data strategy' (4). Both strategies count numerous measures to continue the improvement of open data in Germany. 
Both strategies cover the entirety of Germany. However, some states may have their own strategy for open data that may differ slightly (while maintaining a focus on the four pillars of open data). 
Progressively, institutions were put in place to support this process at the federal level, such as the CCOD that provides support to public administration. It is also worth noting the existence of the IT planungsrat (IT planning council). The IT Planning Council acts as a central political steering body between the federal and state governments on issues relating to information technology and the digitisation of administrative services. All the initiatives related to Open Data fall under the responsibility of the Ministry of Interior, BMI.

SOURCES: 
(1) The Federal Government's National Action Plan to implement the G8 Open Data Charter, 2014. Link: https://www.bmi.bund.de/SharedDocs/downloads/EN/publikationen/2014/national-action-plan-open-data.pdf?__blob=publicationFile
(2) E-Government-Gesetz vom 25. Juli 2013 (BGBl. I S. 2749), das zuletzt durch Artikel 1 des Gesetzes vom 16. Juli 2021 (BGBl. I S. 2941) geändert worden ist. Link: http://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/egovg/BJNR274910013.html

indicators.justification:
The open data framework of Germany is currently undergoing reforms. Germany is working on the transposition of Directive 2019/1024 (Open-Data und Public Sector Information Directive). The legislative and governmental work on this is ongoing and several legislative proposals and new strategies were discussed and adopted after May 2021. 
The Open Data Strategy (different from the Data Strategy) adopted in July 2021 (1) states that the CCOD is working with the Federal Academy for public servants (Bundesakademie für öffentliche Verwaltung - BAköV) on developing introductory training courses for employees of the federal public administration. 
There is currently no evidence that support provided to civil servants goes beyond the guidelines, FAQ and handbook provided by CCOD (2).
Because of the lack of evidence that training exists, the type of support assessed here is the support provided by CCOD through guidelines. Indicators of the elements questions thus refer to the coverage of the support provided by CCOD (especially the handbook on open data). 
Extent questions are not applicable in this case because there is no evidence training is taking place. However, the support provided by CCOD covers all public servants (access is not restricted).

(1) Open-Data-Strategie der Bundesregierung, 2021. indicators.justification:
There is currently no framework for interoperability of datasets in Germany in the area of political integrity. As mentioned in the previous indicators, datasets often take the form of PDF or online information that need to be scrapped from various internet pages. Data is not provided in a structured manner that could allow interoperability and it is currently difficult to have a comprehensive overview. 
However, this is expected to change in the future as the new Data Strategy of the German Government was adopted in January 2021 (1) and the Open data strategy was adopted in July 2021 (2). 
Both documents clearly mention the FAIR principles, highlighting the importance of developing interoperable high quality frameworks.

(1) Datenstrategie der Bundesregierung, 2021. Link: https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/992814/1845634/45aee6da9554115398cc6a722aba08cb/datenstrategie-der-bundesregierung-download-bpa-data.pdf?download=1

indicators.justification:
The EGovG (1) is the main legal framework when it comes to open data. Around this law, there are several agencies and public administrations dealing with open data, such as the data portal DataGov.de, the competence center, the IT planning council. Each of these agencies has different responsibilities and produces guidelines to guide states that produce and publish data. 

In Germany, each state has a data agency and may have its own open data laws and open data portal. DataGov.de is the centralised data portal of Germany. The basis for governing the federal portal DataGov.de is laid down in an administrative agreement that has been signed by 13 out of 16 states (2). 

The Competence Centre on Open Data (CCOD) supports public authorities in implementing the open data framework. The CCOD is the contact point at federal level for states. It provides guidance and produced a handbook on Open Data (3).

The IT planning council (4) deals with technical IT issues, such as format. It decided to use the DCAT-AP as formal standard for open data portal starting in July 2018. 

The EgovG (1) releases data providers from the obligations to check the data for accuracy, completeness, and plausability before publication. The legal framework focuses on the publication of raw data, hence it has not undergone a quality check yet. Available guidelines emphasize that despite the absence of obligation for quality check, data publishers should pay attention to data quality (3).

SOURCES: 
(1) E-Government-Gesetz vom 25. Juli 2013 (BGBl. I S. 2749), das zuletzt durch Artikel 1 des Gesetzes vom 16. Juli 2021 (BGBl. I S. 2941) geändert worden ist. Link: http://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/egovg/BJNR274910013.html 
(2) GovData.de - Das Portal, n.d. Link: https://www.govdata.de/web/guest/hilfe 
(3) CCOD, Open Data Handbuch, n.d. Link: https://www.bva.bund.de/SharedDocs/Downloads/DE/Behoerden/Beratung/Methoden/open_data_handbuch.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=8

indicators.justification:
As per the Members of the Bundestag Act (1), the Bundestag is required to have a code of conduct detailing the requirements for members of the Bundestag. The Code of Conduct (2) states the following: 
Income from outside employment and assets must be declared if it exceeds EUR 1,000 per month or EUR 10,000 per year. 
Donations exceeding EUR 5,000 in calendar year, as well as donations (from the same donor as total) exceeding EUR 10,000 in a calendar year, shall be declared.
Declaration are made to the president of the Bundestag who is also the enforcing authority for the Code of Conduct. The Code of conduct is regularly updated and discussed in the Bundestag. There is no specific reference to updates in the framework but the latest version dates from 2020.
Data is available on the Bundestag website (3). 

Note: this indicator only covers the declaration of interest and assets for members of the Bundestag. The Head of State does not have any requirements to fill in such declaration and Ministers have lighter requirements. 

The EuroPAM survey provides additional information regarding Germany (4).

indicators.justification:
In Germany, the Joint Rules of Procedure for Federal Ministries (1) govern the procedures for participation. Participation and consultation are covered by section 47 to 50 of the Joint Rules of Procedure.
In addition an agreement to increase transparency in legislative procedure also exist, in which publication of the consultations and comments is an explicit requirement (2). 
Consultations are organised by the lead Ministry/Agency that can decide on the timing, scope and choice of stakeholders to consult. Consultations are public and available online on the lead agency/Ministry website. There is no centralised data on public consultation, even though the website of the government has a webpage that gather links and rules for public consultations and on-going legislative procedures (3).

The Global Indicators of regulatory Governance developed by the World Bank also provide a similar analysis. (4) 

SOURCES:
(1) Joint Rules of Procedure of the Federal Ministries (GGO), 2020. Link: https://www.bmi.bund.de/SharedDocs/downloads/EN/themen/moderne-verwaltung/ggo_en.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=6

There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
